original_title: Sri Lanka to have a tax special court: State Minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is proposing to set up special tax courts, State Minister for Finance Ranjith Siyambalpitiya said as the country plans to increase its tax revenues in 2023.

“A series of proposals, including a proposal to open a special court to resolve the legal problems emerging in tax collection is expected to be sent to President Ranil Wickremesinghe for approval,” Minister Siyambalapitiya said in a statement.
Sri Lanka has hiked income tax and is trying to increase its tax to GDP ratio in line with an International Monetary Fund program.
Sri Lanka has increased revenues in the first quarter of 2023, he said.
Sri Lanka should increase tax files from 300,000 to a million, Minister Siyambalapitiya said.

The country’s revenue to GDP ratio fell from 11.9 percent of GDP in 2019 to 8.3 percent of GDP in 2021 as taxes were slashed and the central bank cut rates by printing money in a bid to ‘stimulate’ the economy. (Colombo/ June 29/2023)
